prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: G357.96-0.16
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Source Group I.
SiO, DCN, C18O, CH3CN

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We propose to survey continuum emissions and molecular lines of CH3CN at band 6. Except for target sources, most of the technical justification section are common for all of four Science Goals.
Target sources are listed in the Scientific justification section (Table 1). Tracking center positions are coincident with the 44 GHz methanol maser features. Because distributions of maser features are compact with a typical size of 1000 AU (or 0.2" at 5 kpc; see Scientific justification section) and our target sources are massive star-forming regions possibly haboring massive star clusters (see Figure 2 for example), we need to resolve continuum emissions with 0.2" resolution beam to identify powering sources of target masers. Thus, we propose observations with the highest spatial resolution achieved in cycle 2, 0.2" at 220 GHz. We select band 6 to cover as large field of view as possible and to achieve sufficiently high sensitivities/resolution (band 3 and 4 are excluded for this reason).
We here estimate observing time based on flux densities/brightness temperatures of CH3CN lines at 220 GHz. Using the Cologne Database for Molecular Spectroscopy (CDMS), we calculated expected optical depths of CH3CN lines assuming a column density of 10^16 cm-2 and an excitation temperature of 75 K, which are typical or slightly lower for massive star-forming regions (Beltran et al. 2011). As a result, we found that the CH3CN lines J,K=12,K-11,K lines are optically thick and thermalized for K=0,1,2,3,4. In such cases, brightness temperatures become the same as excitation temperatures of 75 K, and hence, they can be used to estimate the gas temperature directly. On the other hand, optically thin higher-K lines can be used to estimate excitation temperature by a rotation diagram method with at least two transitions. Expected brightness temperatures of the higher-K lines are 67 K and 56 K for K=5 and 6, respectively, corresponding to flux densities of 106 mJy and 90 mJy, respectively. In order to detect these weaker lines with a signal-to-noise ratio of 20 for safety, we will achieve signal-to-noise ratio of 20 (rms=5 mJy) with a frequency resolution of 0.77 kms-1, which is high enough to resolve typical linewidths of massive star-forming regions. In summary, we need 8.15 munutes of on-source time for each pointing. With this on-source time, continuum sensitivity of with a net bandwidth of ~1 GHz for line-free channels are 0.12 mJy. An expected flux density for the most distant source at 15 kpc, although it is not a reliable kinematic distance estimate, is 7.2 mJy assuming a mass of 10 Solar masses and a dust temperature of 50 K. Thus, even the weakest continuum source can be detected with a signal-to-noise ratio grater than 60.
In addition to CH3CN lines, we include C18O and SiO lines to map ambient and shocked molecular gases to study physical properties of molecular clouds and outflows. We expect that these lines are much brighter than the CH3CN lines and hence, easiliy detected. Even though they could not be detected, our science goals will be achieved by present observations of continuum emission and CH3CN lines.
Such a high sensitivity and high spatial resolution observations would request unrealistically long observing time for other arrays, usually one target per full track. Therefore, ALMA is indispensable for our science goals of proposed systematic survey project.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: G49.49-0.39
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Source Group IV.
SiO, DCN, C18O, CH3CN

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The primary goal of our ALMA proposal is to observe continuum emission to identify powering sources of masers. Along with the continuum emissions, we also observe thermal molecular lines of CH3CN at different excitation energy levels to measure gas temperatures by a rotation diagram method. Our motivations are as follows. To reveal formation processes of MYSOs, we take notice of three maser species of 6.7/44 GHz methanol and 22 GHz water masers. These masers are complementary with each other to probe dynamical structures of MYSOs. Currently, we have started observational study of the masers with newly VLBI network of KaVA. A pilot survey of 15 MYSOs associated with the 44 GHz methanol masers (Table 1) has been started in late 2013, and we will extend out survey up to 100 sources within a few years. The goal of our VLBI project are mainly threefold. (1) Clarifying dynamical structures traced by the masers. (2) Establishing dynamical evolution of MYSOs from various tracers (e.g., masers, radio to sub-millimeter continuum emissions). (3) Measuring distances toward our targets from annual parallaxes obtained with VERA. In our VLBI project, synergy with ALMA is indispensable.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: 2013.1.01103.S, 'ALMA Observations of Massive YSOs with Multiple Masers', Mikyoug Kim
